entry.title: AeroDesigns Releases Portland International Jetport for MSFS
entry.summary: Sim: MSFS. AeroDesigns has recently released their rendition of Portland International Jetport (KPWM) for Microsoft Flight Simulator, serving the city of Portland in Maine with a yearly average of 2 million passengers. The airport was conceived in the late 1920s as a landing strip for Dr. Clifford Strange. It saw commercial action for the first time in 1931, with a Boston-Maine Airways flight from Portland to Boston. The city of Portland eventually purchased the airport and renamed it to Portland-Westbrook Municipal Airport, which explains its origin code (PWM). Portland Jetport is served by eleven domestic airlines: American Airlines, American Eagle, Breeze Airways, Delta Air Lines, Delta Connection, Frontier Airlines, JetBlue, Southwest Airlines, Sun Country Airlines, United Airlines, and United Express. Cheapflights consider it the third most affordable airport in New England. Originally intended to be just a port of their KPWM for X-Plane 11, the sceneryâs assets were entirely reworked, including ground textures, ground markings, taxi layout, a complete retexturing of the terminal building (externally and internally) with extra clutter to provide even better immersion. It also includes extra work on details such as dirt, extra ground service equipment, etc.Â It features highly accurate and detailed 3D models of the terminal (internally and externally), detailed landside buildings, custom-modeled jetways, HDR, accurate night lighting, high-resolution ground textures and markings, custom PBR for all textures, accurately placed ground clutter, fully customized runway and taxiway lighting, and a custom GSX profile, packaged into the scenery folder. Itâs available on theÂ Contrail StoreÂ for roughly $18.26 (excluding VAT), requiring at least 1.23 GB of free hard disk space to install. Stay tuned to Threshold for more flight simulation news! â

entry.title: DarkBlueScenery Releases Beijing Capital International Airport for X-Plane 11 & 12
entry.summary: Sim: X-Plane. DarkBlueScenery has recently released their rendition of Beijing Capital International Airport (ZBAA) for X-Plane 11 & 12, one of the two international airports serving the Metropolitan Area of Beijing, in China. Pre-pandemic, the passenger figures sat at a whopping 100 million passengers annually (2018), placing it among the busiest in Asia.Â Opened in March 1958, the airport initially had a single terminal building and a 2,500-meter runway. It was extended to 3,200 meters in 1966 and 3,800 meters in 1982. The second runway was built in 1978, 3,200 meters long. Around that same period came the new Terminal 1, large enough for 12 aircraft but soon proven inadequate given the traffic boom in the 1990s, justifying further expansion that came to fruition in 1999, with the opening of Terminal 2 and a total renovation of Terminal 1.Â The Beijing Olympics called for further expansion work to handle all the extra work, bringing a new runway and a new terminal (T3), which was the largest man-made structure in the World in terms of area coverage. After hosting the Olympics, it quickly rose to the top among the busiest airports in Asia, surpassing Tokyo Haneda. Itâs a hub for Air China and Hainan Airlines, offering a broad domestic and international route network. Itâs visited by many airlines from all over the World, including Air France, Cathay Pacific, Egyptair, Emirates, Etihad Airways, Japan Airlines, LOT Polish Airlines, Lufthansa, Singapore Airlines, Thai Airways, and Turkish Airlines. Cargo-wise, it houses Air China Cargo and China Postal Airlines and gets visited by many cargo carriers from all over, including Cargolux, FedEx, Lufthansa Cargo, and Singapore Airlines Cargo. The scenery features an accurate rendition of the airport, with custom ground markings, high-detail 3D model of the terminal, cargo buildings, custom night lighting, updated ground layout, and more. Itâs available onÂ SimMarketÂ for roughly $16.99, requiring at least 1.31 GB of free hard disk space to install. Stay tuned to Threshold for more flight simulation news! â

entry.title: Barelli MSFS Addon Releases Rome-Ciampino International Airport for MSFS
entry.summary: Sim: MSFS. Barelli MSFS Addon has recently released their rendition of Rome-Ciampino International Airport (LIRA) for Microsoft Flight Simulator, the secondary international airport of Rome, averaging 5 million passengers per year. Ciampino is one of the oldest airports in operation, dating back to 1916. It was the airport of choice for Umberto Nobile on his expedition to the North Pole ten years after the airportâs opening with the airship Norge. It was the first aircraft to reach the north pole and fly across the polar ice cap from Europe to North America. Four years later, Ciampino was the testing ground for the first helicopter prototype, designed by Corradino DâAscanio.Â Captured by the USAF during late World War 2, it became a USAF military airfield, used as a transport air base by C-47 Skytrains, and temporarily flying A-36 Apaches right after its capture from the German forces. â Before the opening of Fiumicino, Ciampino was Romeâs main airport, with an average of 2 million passengers a year. It saw its darkest age during the next couple of decades after Fiumicinoâs opening, handling only charter and executive traffic until low-cost carriers embraced it in the early 2000s. It went from stagnation to one of the fastest-growing airports in Italy, with a whopping 16.75% increase from 2005 to 2006 and 9% from 2006 to 2007, sitting at that 5 million ballpark up until recently (with an apparent drop during the pandemic). Itâs a hub for the low-cost giant Ryanair, with thirty-two European destinations. WizzAir is also a frequent visitor, with six destinations.Â The scenery features a high-detail terminal with custom ground markings, custom ground clutter, a detailed parking lot, landside buildings, and more. Itâs available onÂ SimMarketÂ for roughly $18.27, requiring at least 1.2 GB of free hard disk space to install. Stay tuned to Threshold for more flight simulation news! â

entry.title: The Secret Studio Releases Kuching International Airport for MSFS
entry.summary: Sim: MSFS. The Secret Studio has recently released their rendition of Kuching International Airport (WBGG) for Microsoft Flight Simulator, the fourth busiest airport in Malaysia with a yearly average of 6 million passengers. Kuching Intl serves the southwestern region of Sarawak, in Malaysia, sitting just 11 kilometers south of Kuching. The structure is partially shared with RMAF Kuching, which houses the 7th squadron of the Royal Malaysian Air Force.Â The airport started as an airstrip in 1938, with 640 meters of total length. The first terminal building came nearly 12 years later, relatively small, âLâ shaped, and single-story. The runway then was just 1,372 meters long. With the rapid growth in the 50s, the early 1960s saw further expansion work, with a new runway lengthening and a terminal enlargement.Â The 1970s started with plans to transform Kuching into an international airport, which demanded further runway length and terminal size expansions. It all came to fruition within that decade, with the runway reaching 2,454 meters in length, and the new terminal opened in 1983, replacing the old one with a three-story, 13,000 square meters passenger terminal. The early 2000s brought a massive increase in traffic figures, making the now-old terminal feel cramped. They have decided to build a new terminal from the inside out and progressively replace the old bits. It was inaugurated in January 2006, with full completion in April of that same year. It increased the terminal size from 13,000 to 46,000 square meters, along with a runway extension from the former 2,454 meters to 3,780 meters.Â KIA is served by nine airlines (AirAsia, AirAsia X, Batik Air Malaysia, Firefly, Malaysia Airlines, MASwings, MYAirline, Royal Brunei Airlines, and Scoot), sporting a significant domestic network and a couple of international destinations.Â The scenery features custom-made buildings that match as closely as possible with reference data, a custom CAT I ILS for runway 07, a detailed rendition of the main passenger terminal with its interior, retail booths, and stores, and a custom-made VDGS system. Itâs available onÂ SimMarketÂ for roughly $19.11, requiring at least 467.30 MB of free hard disk space to install. Stay tuned to Threshold for more flight simulation news! â

entry.title: DeltaWing Simulations Releases CRJ-1000 for X-Plane
entry.summary: Sim: X-Plane. DeltaWing Simulations, the developers of the CRJ 700/900 for X-Plane, have released the next model of the CRJ family. The CRJ-1000 is the largest member of the Canadair Regional Jet Family and the final model produced.Â The Mitsubishi CRJ-1000 was originally designed and built by Bombardier Aerospace of Canada. The CRJ-1000 was the final model of the CRJ family. The -1000 was an extension of the earlier models and featured more powerful General Electric engines. This aircraft has a seating capacity for 107 passengers in a single-class layout, which proved to make the aircraft extremely unpopular in the North American regional market. The CRJ-700 was the overwhelmingly more successful model of the family. This was due to the United States Regional Carriers being limited by scope clauses set by the larger mainline aircraft. The CRJ-1000 ended production in 2018 having only produced 63 units.Â The DeltaWing CRJ-1000 has many features users of their CRJ 700/900 products will already be familiar with, a brief feature list is as follows: â To find the complete feature list, or to purchase the aircraft, please visit the X-Plane.org Store. This aircraft will cost $49.95 USD and is X-Plane 12 compatible only. Existing owners of the CRJ-700 or -900 can find a coupon for 30% off with the invoice for your original purchase.

It serves Chios, the fifth-largest Greek island. Owned by the government, Chios Airport started its operations in mid-1969 with an Olympic Airways flight from Athens. It underwent several upgrades, including a new passenger terminal in the 1980s. According to Greek Travel Pages, the airport recently received 9.6 million euros in funding from the National Strategic Reference Framework to upgrade the infrastructure and facilities, expanding the terminal to comport higher traffic figures. Deputy Minister Giorgios Karagiannis has mentioned itâs part of a broader plan to modernize the airports in the country. With a single, 1,511-meter-long runway, it mostly gets regional traffic from either Olympic Air or Sky Expressâ ATR fleet, but it can fit up to an Airbus A320/ Boeing 738. The airlines mentioned above are the only ones currently serving the airport, with frequent flights to Athens, Thessaloniki, Lemnos, Mytilene, Rhodes, and Samos.Â The scenery features hand-made ground textures, true-to-life landside recreation with custom ground decals, signposts, vegetation, parking barriers, and more, accurate real-world decals and advertisements, accurately placed lighting, surrounding objects including shops and boats, and hand-placed ground service equipment properly scattered around.Â Itâs available on theÂ iniBuilds StoreÂ for roughly $8.58, requiring at least 1.84 GB of free hard disk space to install.
